content: Steele trap? GOP fears grow <snip>A month after Michael Steele became the first African-American chairman of the Republican National Committee, key party leaders are worried that the GOP has made a costly mistake — one that will make it even harder for them to take back power from the dominant Democratic Party. Steadily becoming a dependable punch line, Steele has brushed back Rush Limbaugh, threatened moderate Republican senators, offered the “friggin’ awesome” Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal some “slum love,” called civil unions “crazy” and promised more outreach to “urban-suburban hip-hop settings” via an “off the hook” public relations campaign. On the organizational side, Steele does not have a chief of staff, a political director, a finance director or a communications director. Last week, one of the two men sharing the job of interim finance director was forced to resign. For now, “the fourth floor,” as the RNC’s executive suite is known, is being run by a pair of consultants. <snip> "http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0309/19588.html" The GOP has had their asses handed to them in the last two elections. They are desperately casting about for leadership in their party while trying to "appeal to the masses". They tried Sarah Palin (Hey look, we have a chick). They tried Piyush Jindal (and we all know how that is turning out) and they tried Michael Steele (Hey look we have a black guy). Sorry kids...don't you get that it isn't just ANY "black guy"? It is no wonder Rush Limbaugh is being touted as the de facto (or is it de fatso?) leader of the GOP. He certainly is a good fit...bloated, drug addled and puffed up with self importance...

content: Not being a registered Republican I never thought the selection of M Steele was the best choice [smacked of "ha! we have one too!"] That being said Steele spoke of certain laudible goals-expanding the base-reaching out to non traditional R voters etc. His "hip-hop" strategy really finished him for me.Unprofessional, buffoonish downright uneffective. Perhaps one of the Rs on the board could suggest a reasonable alternative.Im pretty sure Steele-no matter how well intentioned,isnt it.
reply: Not being a registered Republican I never thought the selection of M Steele was the best choice [smacked of "ha! we have one too!"] That being said Steele spoke of certain laudible goals-expanding the base-reaching out to non traditional R voters etc. His "hip-hop" strategy really finished him for me.Unprofessional, buffoonish downright uneffective. Perhaps one of the Rs on the board could suggest a reasonable alternative.Im pretty sure Steele-no matter how well intentioned,isnt it.

content: Give the Democrats time, they will do exactly as the Republican did, over reach. Markets are tanking, unemployment is increasing and the GDP is stagnant. Maybe President Obama will survive because of his popularity, but if things continue downward the Congress will pay the price.

content: quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: ...they tried Michael Steele (Hey look we have a black guy). Sorry kids...don't you get that it isn't just ANY "black guy"? It is no wonder Rush Limbaugh is being touted as the de facto (or is it de fatso?) leader of the GOP. He certainly is a good fit...bloated, drug addled and puffed up with self importance... Seems to me it's Dems who ought to be asking the same question of themselves with your "just ANY black guy" assertion. The Dems never cared about Obama's radical associations and Marxist philosophies (ask Joe the plumber about that)--skin color was the ONLY issue for Dems in the last election. "Content of character" sounds like hollow words coming from Democrats who trashed good people like Justice Thomas, Condi Rice, Colin Powell and other African American Republicans, using racial insults and stereotypes that for some reason seem to be okay with everyone when Dems say them. It's also funny how they have an admitted pot-head in the oval office (maybe that's why he needs a teleprompter all the time) and it's still all about Limbaugh's addiction to painkillers. And all this time I thought liberals were sensitive and caring about people with addictions. Guess not. By the way, I always wonder why Dems seem more "concerned" about the Republican party than a lot of us conservatives. I see fear--fear that Republicans will catch on, start ditching the RINO's that keep selling out to the Dems, and return to the conservative principles that puts Dems back out on their Socialist rear-ends.

content: quote: Originally posted by bill_kananen: quote: karlhungusjr: So it's "just" about color when everyone votes for the black guy? It's more about what the "black guy" says. Obama was well received because he knew how to address his audience. Jackson and Sharpton are playing to a different audience. That's because, according to our Vice President, President Obama was the first African-American in politics who was clean, articulate, and bright. I had told one of my friends that while I didn't like the hippies, I respected the fact that they at least cared enough to do something. I asked him what our generation (born in 1980) will be known for. His response was that our generation might elect the first black or female President, as though that were an end in and of itself. This was a couple of years before the primaries, so Obama wasn't even a household name at the time. Take from that what you will.
